articles.headline: Will Florida, the Recount State, Be Ready for the Election?
articles.snippet: Elections supervisors say the hard-earned lessons of the 2000 presidential recount and other messes have taught them well. But the challenges are already apparent.
articles.abstract: Elections supervisors say the hard-earned lessons of the 2000 presidential recount and other messes have taught them well. But the challenges are already apparent.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Most states have the occasional problems running their elections. Not Florida. Florida has debacles.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs Is Said to Admit Mistakes in 1MDB Scandal
articles.snippet: A foreign subsidiary of the Wall Street giant will plead guilty under an agreement with the Justice Department, according to a person familiar with the deal.
articles.abstract: A foreign subsidiary of the Wall Street giant will plead guilty under an agreement with the Justice Department, according to a person familiar with the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: An Asian subsidiary of Goldman Sachs will plead guilty to charges in the United States to resolve a foreign corruption and bribery case over the looting of billions of dollars from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund, according to a person familiar with the agreement.

articles.headline: Google Up Against Laws That Thwarted Microsoft (and Others Since 1890)
articles.snippet: The Justice Department’s antitrust case points to restrictive contracts, a focus that a professor said “is as old as the Sherman Act.”
articles.abstract: The Justice Department’s antitrust case points to restrictive contracts, a focus that a professor said “is as old as the Sherman Act.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, House lawmakers concluded a 16-month investigation into Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook and called for sweeping changes to curb their market power. The lawmakers’ verdict: Traditional antitrust laws aren’t up to the challenge, and the laws need their biggest overhaul in more than 40 years.

articles.headline: Trump Records Shed New Light on Chinese Business Pursuits
articles.snippet: As he raises questions about his opponent’s standing with China, President Trump’s taxes reveal details about his own activities there, including a previously unknown bank account.
articles.abstract: As he raises questions about his opponent’s standing with China, President Trump’s taxes reveal details about his own activities there, including a previously unknown bank account.
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire, Russ Buettner and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: McConnell Moves to Head Off Stimulus Deal as Pelosi Reports Progress
articles.snippet: The top Senate Republican told colleagues that he had advised the White House against striking a pre-election deal with Democrats to deliver pandemic aid, fearing political repercussions.
articles.abstract: The top Senate Republican told colleagues that he had advised the White House against striking a pre-election deal with Democrats to deliver pandemic aid, fearing political repercussions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, privately told Republican senators on Tuesday that he had warned the White House not to strike a pre-election deal with Speaker Nancy Pelosi on a new round of stimulus, moving to head off an agreement that President Trump has demanded but most in his party oppose.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: The Police Can Probably Break Into Your Phone
articles.snippet: At least 2,000 law enforcement agencies have tools to get into encrypted smartphones, according to new research, and they are using them far more than previously known.
articles.abstract: At least 2,000 law enforcement agencies have tools to get into encrypted smartphones, according to new research, and they are using them far more than previously known.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a new Apple ad, a man on a city bus announces he has just shopped for divorce lawyers. Then a woman recites her credit card number through a megaphone in a park. “Some things shouldn’t be shared,” the ad says, “iPhone helps keep it that way.”

articles.headline: The Fed’s $4 Trillion Lifeline Never Materialized. Here’s Why.
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve was meant to take $454 billion and drastically expand it. So far, it has lent $20 billion.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve was meant to take $454 billion and drastically expand it. So far, it has lent $20 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As companies furloughed millions of workers and stock prices plunged through late March, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin offered a glimmer of hope: The government was about to step in with a $4 trillion bazooka.

articles.headline: A Biden Landslide? Some Democrats Can’t Help Whispering
articles.snippet: Democrats are still haunted by the ghosts of 2016. But some are allowing themselves to contemplate a Biden victory big enough to reorder the nation’s politics.
articles.abstract: Democrats are still haunted by the ghosts of 2016. But some are allowing themselves to contemplate a Biden victory big enough to reorder the nation’s politics.

articles.headline: Google Antitrust Fight Thrusts Low-Key C.E.O. Into the Line of Fire
articles.snippet: Sundar Pichai, chief executive of Google’s parent company for less than a year, already faces the internet giant’s biggest threat in its 22 years.
articles.abstract: Sundar Pichai, chief executive of Google’s parent company for less than a year, already faces the internet giant’s biggest threat in its 22 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When Sundar Pichai succeeded Larry Page as the head of Google’s parent company in December, he was handed a bag of problems: Shareholders had sued the company, Alphabet, over big financial packages handed to executives accused of misconduct. An admired office culture was fraying. Most of all, antitrust regulators were circling.

articles.headline: Activists Turn Facial Recognition Tools Against the Police
articles.snippet: “We’re now approaching the technological threshold where the little guys can do it to the big guys,” one researcher said.
articles.abstract: “We’re now approaching the technological threshold where the little guys can do it to the big guys,” one researcher said.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early September, the City Council in Portland, Ore., met virtually to consider sweeping legislation outlawing the use of facial recognition technology. The bills would not only bar the police from using it to unmask protesters and individuals captured in surveillance imagery; they would also prevent companies and a variety of other organizations from using the software to identify an unknown person.

articles.headline: In Shift for Church, Pope Francis Voices Support for Same-Sex Civil Unions
articles.snippet: The comments, shown in a new documentary, are the strongest yet from a pontificate that has taken a more tolerant and inclusive tone.
articles.abstract: The comments, shown in a new documentary, are the strongest yet from a pontificate that has taken a more tolerant and inclusive tone.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis expressed support for same-sex civil unions in remarks revealed in a documentary film that premiered on Wednesday, a significant break from his predecessors that staked out new ground for the church in its recognition of gay people.

articles.headline: In Azerbaijan, Pain and Loss Drive War Fever
articles.snippet: As the country’s soldiers advance in the conflict with Armenia, every “liberated” territory is celebrated and tens of thousands of refugees plan their return to lost lands.
articles.abstract: As the country’s soldiers advance in the conflict with Armenia, every “liberated” territory is celebrated and tens of thousands of refugees plan their return to lost lands.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAKU, Azerbaijan — As dusk fell, the sound of wailing carried on the soft evening breeze. Women filled the courtyard of a small house, keening over a coffin draped in the national flag. Men clustered in hushed groups in the narrow alley outside.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett
